data.title: Looking back at 20 years of Skylands Park history
data.meta_description: Here is a chronology of important events in the history of Skylands Park:
data.text:
Here is a chronology of important events in the history of Skylands Park:

February 1991: Robert Hilliard, president of developer Skylands Park Management, purchases the Hamilton (Ontario) Redbirds, a Class A minor league baseball team affiliated with Major League Baseball's St. Louis Cardinals. He and his business partners decide that Sussex County is a great place to relocate the team.

Feb. 12, 1992: Hilliard makes a presentation to the Sussex County League of Municipalities projecting $1.2 million in annual revenues from a proposed $5.4 million baseball stadium and sports complex, to be named Skylands Park.

April 23, 1992: After determining that nearby wetlands would interfere with construction, Hilliard announces that Skylands Park will not be built at the intersection of routes 565 and 23 in Wantage.

June 3, 1992: Skylands Park Management reaches an agreement with Branchville's High Point Financial Corp. to build Skylands Park at Ross' Corner at the intersection of routes 206, 15 and 565 in Frankford.

Sept. 16, 1992: The developers' first application for a use variance approval is heard and granted by the Frankford Zoning Board.

Sept. 21, 1992: The New York-Penn League votes to approve the relocation of the Hamilton Redbirds to Skylands Park. The Redbirds are also approved to play their 1993 season in Glen Falls, N.Y., in the interim.

Jan. 7, 1993: Newton architectural firm Houghton-Quarty Warr is chosen to oversee construction of Skylands Park.

Feb. 10, 1993: The Frankford Zoning Board unanimously approves preliminary site plans and subdivision for Skylands Park, paving the way for construction.

Mid-July 1993: Ground is broken at the site of the complex.

Aug. 19, 1993: Skylands Park Management hosts a public groundbreaking ceremony for the ballpark at Ross' Corner.

Sept. 15, 1993: Skylands Park Management officially purchases the 28-acre, $1.1 million tract of land for the complex from High Point Financial Corp.

Early November, 1993: Planting of the infield and outfield turf grass at Skylands Park is completed.

April 12, 1994: The New Jersey Cardinals sell out the alotted 2,100 season tickets for their inaugural season.

April 17, 1994: About 300 people attend the first-ever baseball game held at Skylands Park, a college doubleheader between Sussex County Community College and Burlington County College. SCCC wins both games, 5-4 and 10-3.

June 1, 1994: Skylands Park Management files for Chapter 11 bankruptcy re-organization after falling $4.5 million in debt to its contractors due to winter weather-related cost overruns. Despite the developer's financial troubles, the Cardinals are allowed to play at Skylands Park for the 1994 season.

June 16, 1994: State Sen. Robert Littell throws out the first pitch at the Cardinals' season-opening game at Skylands Park, a 6-3 win over the Hudson Valley Renegades. The game draws a capacity crowd of 4,200.

Aug. 16, 1994: The Cardinals break the New York-Penn League's then-season attendance record after drawing 4,522 fans to Skylands Park for their win over the Renegades; over 26 home games, they attract a total of 103,521 fans.

September 1994: The Cardinals claim the New York-Penn League championship in their first season in Frankford after defeating the Auburn Astros 2-0.

April 13, 1995: Skylands Park Management wins approval from a U.S. bankruptcy judge to proceed with its reorganization plans and get out of debt.

May 1995: Skylands Park is finally completed.

Oct. 3, 2005: After failed efforts to convince stadium owners to upgrade Skylands Park or county government to construct a new one, Cardinals General Manager Tony Torre confirms that the team's owners have reached a tentative agreement to move the Cardinals to a brand-new stadium in State College, Pa. The deal goes through, and the Cardinals become the State College Spikes of the New York-Penn League for the 2006 season.

Jan. 5, 2006: Sussex Professional Baseball, an investor group run by businessman Floyd Hall and his son, Larry, reaches a deal with Skylands Park operator Millennium Sports Management (formerly Skylands Park Management) to bring an independent team from the Canadian-American League to Frankford. Much of the new team's initial roster is made up of players from the Grays, a traveling team from the league that folded after the 2005 season.

Jan. 25, 2006: County resident and avid Yankees fan Michael Bruno, 68, wins Sussex Professional Baseball's competition to name the new team at Skylands Park. His suggestion, the "Skyhawks," is chosen from a field of more than 2,500 entries.

May 29, 2006: The Skyhawks play the first home game of their inaugural season at Skylands Park, the first game of a three-game series with the North Shore Spirit. They lose in an 18-11 shootout.

Sept. 12, 2008: After going 66-117 in their first two years, the Skyhawks capture the Can-Am League championship with a 10-5 victory over the Quebec Capitales, winning the series 2-1.

Aug. 29, 2010: The Skyhawks play their final home game of the 2010 season, a 4-3 win over the Pittsfield Colonials. The game proves to be the Skyhawks' last contest at Skylands Park.

September 2010: Several announcements on the Skyhawks' Facebook page cast doubt on the team's future. The comments indicate that Floyd Hall has put the team up for sale and is seeking to "unload the (Skyhawks) from his portfolio" to focus on another team he owns, the New Jersey Jackals of Little Falls.

Jan. 10, 2011: The Can-Am League declares the Skyhawks inoperable for the 2011 season, officially confirming that they will not return to Skylands Park. The Skyhawks are replaced on the league's roster by the Rockland Boulders, a new expansion franchise based in Ramapo, N.Y., and the New York Federals, a traveling team made up of players from the New York State League.
